courseDescription: Introductory course emphasizing the geology, chemistry, physics and biology of the oceans. Laboratory emphasizes practice of basic scientific methods. Knowledge of the metric system, scientific notation, ratio and proportion, and graphing is required. Field trip required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to graph and interpret data
Application of geology, chemistry, physics and biology in oceanography
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to work in a team during field trips
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use ratio and proportion in problem-solving
Application of scientific methods in laboratory work

courseDescription: What is the science behind global climate change?  How reliable are forecasts of future global warming?  This course examines these questions to evaluate the likelihood and potential severity of anthropogenic climate change in the coming centuries.  It includes an overview of the physics of the greenhouse effect, an overview of the global carbon cycle and its role as a global thermostat; an examination of predictions and reliability of model forecasts of future climate change; and examination of local impacts of global climate change (e.g., sea level rise in the Tidewater area).
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of the global carbon cycle
Evaluation of climate change model forecasts
Identifying impacts of global climate change
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex climate concepts in simple terms
Discussing climate change impacts and forecasts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing reliability of climate change forecasts
Evaluating the severity of potential climate change
Understanding the causes and effects of global climate change

courseDescription: This is an introductory course in geological sciences.  The course relates the principles of natural science to Earth as a planet, its resources, and its environment.  The effects of geologic processes on the environment are stressed.  A student receiving credit for OEAS 110N cannot receive credit for OEAS 111N.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Earth as a planet
Understanding of Earth's resources and environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of geologic processes on the environment

courseDescription: This course introduces the student to the study of the materials, structures, and processes of the Earth.  Present terrestrial resources are interpreted in terms of the internal and surface processes that formed them. A student receiving credit for OEAS 111N cannot receive credit for OEAS 110N.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Earth's internal and surface processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding processes that form terrestrial resources

courseDescription: The evolution of the continents, ocean basins, mountain chains, and the major life forms throughout Earth's history are studied chronologically and are related to the physical and biological changes that have caused them.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of physical changes and their impacts

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  Special honors section of OEAS 106N.  In addition to broad coverage of the geology, chemistry, physics and biology of the ocean, students will read scientific papers with current environmental problems.  There will be several field trips to nearby ecosystems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and analysis of scientific literature
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and execution of field trips
Time management for complex scientific reading

courseTitle: Research Skills and Information Literacy for the Natural Sciences
courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to a range of research and information literacy skills necessary for natural scientists. The course will introduce students to the wide range of research being undertaken in the natural sciences (e.g., oceanography, geology, physics, biology, and chemistry). The course involves directed reading, exercises in information retrieval, and the synthesis of information from a range of sources into scientific essays and oral presentations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of research methods in natural sciences

courseDescription: Special topics in physical, geological, chemical or biological oceanography.

courseTitle: Undergraduate Research Experience in Ocean and Earth Sciences
courseDescription: Student participation in a supervised, undergraduate research experience for which credit will not apply to the degree.  Experience must be related to the student's major, minor or career area of interest.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research methods in ocean and earth sciences
Use of scientific software and tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with research supervisors and team

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the basic principles governing both day-to-day weather and the average of weather, or climate. Specific focus will be given to the tools used to measure weather and the ways in which these tools have impacted our understanding of weather in the past and present. Links will be made between the technology-based improvements of our understanding of weather and the impact on the lives of humans throughout recent history. Students will learn about how weather forecasts are made, and how the quality of these forecasts affects our lives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of meteorology tools and technology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding the relevance of weather forecasts to everyday life
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of weather forecasts

courseDescription: An investigation of a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography.
Geologic resources and processes that limit human activities and pose significant hazards.  Does not satisfy OEAS major degree or minor requirements.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of geologic limitations on human activities

courseDescription: This course introduces the concepts of paleontology, focusing on the relationship between the evolution of life (particularly invertebrates) and the development of Earth.  Field work will also include studies in paleoecology and sedimentary facies. Two field trips are recommended.

General survey of physical, geological, chemical and biological oceanography.  The application of skills from mathematics, geology, physics, biology and chemistry for the solution of oceanographic problems.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation from different scientific fields

courseDescription: In this course-based undergraduate research experience, students perform field and laboratory experiments designed to complement topics presented in the Oceanography lecture course, OEAS 306.  Students taking OEAS 306 are strongly encouraged to take this laboratory class concurrently with OEAS 306.  Ocean and Earth Science majors are required to take this class.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in field and lab settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in experimental design and execution

courseDescription: Core course for ocean and earth sciences majors that examines the processes linking the Earth's atmosphere, lithosphere, and hydrosphere into an interactive system.

The course introduces the main igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks and their mineral composition. Laboratory exercises include mineral identification by physical and microscopic optical properties, the identification of rocks in hand samples, and basic training with the Brunton compass. Field work includes training in introductary facies analysis, and the analysis of sedimentary rock structures, unconformities, volcanic, plutonic, and metamorphic rock units, clastics and carbonates.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mineral identification through microscopic optical properties
Identification of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks in hand samples
Basic operation of the Brunton compass
Analysis of volcanic, plutonic, and metamorphic rock units
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of volcanic, plutonic, and metamorphic rock units

courseDescription: The origin, transport, and deposition of sediments with emphasis on interpretation of sediment sequences, principles and methods of correlation.  Laboratory exercises involve field sampling, textural analyses, and sedimentary structures.  Field trip required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of sediment origin, transport, and deposition

courseDescription: Geologic processes that shape the earth's surface.  Laboratory studies involve interpretation of topographic maps, soil maps, and aerial photographs.  Field trip required. This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Recognition and interpretation of geomorphic features

courseTitle: Where Rivers Meet the Sea: Ecology and Climate
courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the highly productive ecosystems of estuaries that result from the interactions of fresh and oceanic waters. The course includes exploration, evaluation, and analysis of the factors that allow construction of realistic conceptual models of an important Earth system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of fresh and oceanic water interactions

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the Career Management program prior to the semester in which the experience is to take place.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a professional setting
Clear articulation of academic relevance of work experience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of academic principles in practical situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and adhering to established criteria

courseTitle: Internship in Ocean and Earth Sciences
courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Students gain on the job work experience related to their undergraduate curriculum.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ocean and earth sciences
Application of scientific principles in a professional setting

courseTitle: Practicum in Ocean, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courseDescription: Field experience in ocean, earth and atmospheric sciences. (qualifies as a CAP experience)
Lectures, field and laboratory studies. An investigation of a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis from field and laboratory studies

courseTitle: Field Experiences in Oceanography for Teachers
courseDescription: Field and laboratory experiences in oceanography including hands-on experience using equipment and methods suitable for middle and secondary education professionals.  Course will provide understanding of oceanic processes using simple field and laboratory experiments.  Not available for credit for OES majors and minors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of oceanic processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching complex concepts to middle and secondary education students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of laboratory and field data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and conducting field and laboratory experiences

courseDescription: This course will present basic ecological principles relevant to water pollution and ecotoxicology. Topics will include runoff, eutrophication, water and sewage treatment, industrial waste, oil pollution, pesticides, and plastics in the sea. Case studies provide focal points for consideration of issues in making decisions and setting policy. This is a writing intensive course. Pre- or
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of water and sewage treatment processes
Knowledge of effects of pesticides and plastics in the sea
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Writing intensive course requires strong written communication skills
Ability to articulate complex ecological issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to prioritize and organize information
Leadership in decision making and policy setting

courseDescription: Physics of the ocean: properties of seawater and their distribution; water mass formation; mass and energy flows; waves; tides; models; estuarine and coastal processes.  An elective for science and engineering majors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex scientific concepts
Collaboration with peers on scientific projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in oceanic and coastal processes
Interpretation and analysis of oceanic models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying scientific concepts in real-world scenarios

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to Matlab programming and to develop skills utilizing this program for data analysis
Chemical composition of the ocean and the chemical, biological, geological and physical processes controlling it.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biological, geological, and physical processes

courseDescription: An examination of the development of the earth as a habitable planet, from its origin to human impacts on global biogeochemical cycles on land, and in the oceans and atmosphere.
Technical and Digital Skills: Insight into human impacts on global cycles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying effects of human impacts on global cycles

courseDescription: This course examines geochemical processes at and near the Earth’s surface, focusing on the concentration, speciation and reactivity of elements in soils, waters, sediments and the atmosphere.  The course examines both the thermodynamic and kinetic controls on these processes, and the role of biology as a mediator (or facilitator) of these processes.  Anthropogenic impacts on natural geochemical processes are also examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of element concentration, speciation and reactivity in various environments
Understanding of thermodynamic and kinetic controls on geochemical processes
Ability to examine the role of biology in geochemical processes
Knowledge of anthropogenic impacts on geochemical processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex geochemical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills to understand complex geochemical processes
Ability to interpret the impact of anthropogenic activities on natural processes
Problem-solving skills to examine and understand the role of biology in geochemical processes

courseDescription: Causes, nature, measurement and analysis of water waves and tides.  Mathematical and graphical application to wave and tide problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mathematical application in water wave and tide analysis
Graphical application in water wave and tide analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of water waves and tides
Problem solving in wave and tide issues

courseDescription: The course will consist of brief lectures and hands-on laboratory exercises, in which students will learn to build, use, and debug electronic devices relevant to ocean and earth science applications.  Topics covered will include circuit theory, power supplies and budgets, transducers and amplifiers, computerized data acquisition, instrument control, signal conditioning and resolution.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Practical application of electronics and oceanographic instrumentation

courseDescription: Chemical cycling in lakes and reservoirs, and interactions with biological and physical processes; quantitative modeling of lake geochemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Chemical cycling in lakes and reservoirs
Understanding of biological and physical processes in lakes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing chemical interactions with biological and physical processes

courseDescription: The course integrates remotely sensed and field techniques for scientific investigation and practical management of coastal environmental systems.  Spatial modeling of coastal processes and management tools using geographic information system (GIS).
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Scientific investigation of coastal environmental systems
Practical management of coastal environmental systems

courseDescription: Topics covered will include the occurrence and movement of surface and subsurface water, the nature and distribution of permeable rocks and strata, field techniques used in ground-water studies, and the flow of ground-water to wells.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of surface and subsurface water movement
Knowledge of permeable rocks and strata
Proficiency in field techniques used in ground-water studies
Understanding of ground-water flow to wells

courseDescription: Survey of marine geology and geophysics; plate tectonics and basin formation; seafloor volcanic activity; marine sediments and sediment dynamics; coastal processes; geologic time in the marine record.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of plate tectonics and basin formation
Analysis of marine sediments and sediment dynamics
Understanding geologic time in the marine record
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems related to basin formation
Interpreting geologic time in marine records

courseDescription: This web-based course will provide a practical introduction to oceanography for earth science teachers.  It is particularly aimed at current science teachers attempting to become certified in earth science education.  Topics will include discussions of geological, biological, physica and chemical oceanography.  Not available for credit for OEAS majors and minors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion participation in an online environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of geological, biological, physical and chemical oceanography topics
Identification and understanding of oceanographic processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guidance for students in earth science
Planning and execution of science education curriculum

courseDescription: Introduction to the physics of the earth, including plate tectonics, volcanism, earthquakes and seismology, gravity, the Earth's magnetic field, geophysical remote sensing, and mantle convection.

A qualitative and quantitative description of physical processes in the Earth and environmental sciences. Topics include stress and strain, plate elasticity and flexure, heat flow, fluid mechanics, material rheology, and groundwater flow. Emphasis will be placed on developing an understanding of Earth dynamics using real-world examples, including numerical exercises.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical processes in Earth and environmental sciences
Understanding of plate elasticity and flexure

courseTitle: Introduction to Ocean Modeling and Prediction
courseDescription: Introduction to concepts and theories of numerical ocean circulation models and their applications in physical oceanography, computational fluid dynamics, environmental problems and ocean forecast systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of numerical ocean circulation models
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex environmental problems and solutions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving environmental problems using ocean models
Predicting ocean behavior using numerical models
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing ocean forecast systems

courseDescription: Marine organisms and their relationship to physical and chemical processes in the ocean. Laboratory study of local marine organisms, marine ecosystem and sampling techniques.  Includes identification, data analysis and field trips.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of physical and chemical oceanic processes

courseTitle: Ocean and Earth Sciences Field Study I
courseDescription: Interdisciplinary investigation of selected sites in Southeast Virginia that includes field sampling, sample analyses, data interpretation and integration, and group report preparation and presentations.  Focuses on development of research questions and site selection, field sampling, sample analyses and interpretation.  Oral presentations of results will be made by each student.

courseTitle: Ocean and Earth Sciences Field Study II
courseDescription: Interdisciplinary investigation of selected sites in Southeast Virginia that includes field sampling, sample analyses, data interpretation and integration, and group report preparation and presentations.  Focuses on site selection and evaluation mapping, sampling, and sample analyses.  Oral presentations of results will be made by each student.  This is a writing intensive course.

courseTitle: Communicating Ocean Science to Informal Audiences
courseDescription: Communicating Science to Informal Audiences (CoSIA) is designed for students interested in improving their ability to communicate scientific knowledge by presenting information and activities in an informal learning environment. The course combines instruction in inquiry-based science teaching with practical experience presenting to guests of all ages at the Virginia Aquarium. Students will practice communicating knowledge and receive mentoring on how to improve their presentations. CoSIA provides future scientists and educators with a background in current learning theory and applies it through practical experiences to empower them to meet communication challenges they will encounter in their careers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Presenting scientific information in an informal learning environment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting communication style to different audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of learning theory in practical experiences
Improvement of presentation skills through feedback and mentorship
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing information presentation to diverse audiences
Leading educational activities at the Virginia Aquarium

courseTitle: Communicating Ocean Science to Informal Audiences
courseDescription: This course provides Earth Science Education students with instruction on presenting scientific information to informal audiences (K through adult).  Students will develop more in-depth presentations and extended practice presenting their materials on the Virginia Aquarium floor.  For Earth Science Education track students, OEAS 444 and OEAS 445 can replace OEAS 441/OEAS 442W.  It is available as an elective for all other students.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse age groups
Explaining complex scientific concepts in simple terms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting presentation content to audience understanding level
Evaluating audience engagement and adjusting presentation accordingly
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading educational sessions in a public setting

courseTitle: Data Collection and Analysis in Oceanography
courseDescription: This course introduces students to the basic numerical tools used to obtain and analyze information in the ocean and earth sciences.  The students will use various oceanographic instruments to obtain data at different locations of the Chesapeake Bay.  Data obtained with those instruments will be processed and analyzed using data analysis techniques discussed in class.  The data will then be used to answer a particular question related to the temporal and spatial variability in a natural system.  This is a writing intensive class.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing temporal and spatial variability in natural systems
Applying data to answer specific questions

courseDescription: Marine microbes thrive in all oceanic habitats including what would be considered extreme environmental conditions. This course studies the role that these microbes play in biogeochemical cycling and food web dynamics in the oceans (the microbial loop). Throughout the course, students will learn about different microbial functional groups and the processes they mediate in marine systems, which include virtually all geochemical reactions occurring in the oceans.  Students will learn through lectures, readings written by experts in the field, and class discussions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of oceanic microbial functional groups
Understanding of geochemical reactions occurring in the oceans
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Synthesizing and conveying complex scientific concepts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-directed learning through lectures and readings
Time management for course materials review

courseDescription: This course will explore the ecology of marine organisms using molecular techniques and data. Molecular ecology covers a wide variety of sub-disciplines, including genetics, physiology, ecology, and evolution. The course will explore basic theory in population genetics, ecology, and evolution and cover nucleic acid techniques and their applications. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of genetics, physiology, ecology and evolution
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of molecular techniques in marine ecology
Understanding of population genetics, ecology, and evolution

courseTitle: Introduction to Mitigation and Adaptation Studies
courseDescription: Students will be introduced to the science underpinning mitigation of human-induced changes in the Earth system, including but not limited to climate change and sea level rise, and adaptation to the impacts of these changes. The course will cover the environmental hazards and the opportunities and limitations for conservation, mitigation and adaptation. This is a writing intensive course. Cross listed with BIOL 466W and IDS 466W.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in mitigation of human-induced changes
Understanding of conservation opportunities and limitations

courseDescription: In this class, students will discover what makes a leader for sustainability. They will consider a range of global and local crises from a leadership point of view in the context of sustainability science, which addresses the development of communities in a rapidly changing social, economic, and environmental system-of-systems environment. The course will be based on taking a problem-motivated and solution-focused approach to the challenges considered. The course includes a service learning project focusing on a leadership experience in solving a real-world environmental problem.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of sustainability issues and solutions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of global and local crises
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for service learning projects

courseTitle: Research Methods in Math and Sciences
courseDescription: Emphasizes the tools and techniques used to solve scientific problems. Topics include use and design of experiments, use of statistics to interpret experimental results, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena, and oral and written presentation of results. Students will perform four independent inquiries, combining skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use and design of scientific experiments
Application of statistics to interpret experimental results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving using mathematical and scientific skills

courseTitle: Proxy Reconstruction of Late Cenozoic Climate: Calibrations and Applications
courseDescription: This course will examine recent developments in paleo-proxy calibration and their application in reconstructing Late Cenozoic climate history. Students will read several papers covering the theoretical basis and empirical evidence supporting some of the most common proxies used in paleoclimatology/paleoceanography each week. Each week will begin with a lecture on the topic, followed by an in-depth discussion. Students will be required to present one of the weekly topics and lead the class discussion.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and explaining complex scientific papers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theoretical knowledge to practical climate history reconstruction

courseTitle: Honors Research in Ocean and Earth Sciences
courseDescription: Supervised study in a field of individual interest.  Research results are reported in a public oral presentation and a thesis.

This course will provide an overview of how marine sediments are used to reconstruct Earth's climate history over the past 600 million years. Students will discuss the factors that control modern climate and explore how these variables led to cycles of Greenhouse and Icehouse worlds in the past. Finally, students will discuss how past and modern climate records can be used to predict future climate change.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of climate cycles

courseDescription: Lectures, field and laboratory studies.  An investigation of a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Reporting findings from studies and investigations

courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected with the direction of an instructor.

courseTitle: Field Experiences in Oceanography for Teachers
courseDescription: Field and laboratory experiences in oceanography including hands-on experience using equipment and methods suitable for middle and secondary education professionals.  Course will provide understanding of oceanic processes using simple field and laboratory experiments.  Not available for credit for OES majors and minors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Execution of field and laboratory experiments
Understanding and application of oceanic processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching practical skills to middle and secondary education students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing results of field and laboratory experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and conducting field and laboratory experiments

courseDescription: This course will present basic ecological principles relevant to water pollution and ecotoxicology.  Topics will include runoff, eutrophication, water and sewage treatment, industrial waste, oil pollution, pesticides, and plastics in the sea.  Case studies provide focal points for consideration of issues in making decisions and setting policy. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of water and sewage treatment processes
Knowledge of oil pollution and its effects
Identifying and analyzing effects of pesticides and plastics in the sea
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Policy and decision-making based on aquatic pollution case studies

courseDescription: Physics of the ocean: properties of seawater and their distribution; water mass formation; mass and energy flows; waves; tides; models; estuarine and coastal processes.  An elective for science and engineering majors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of mass and energy flows
Understanding of estuarine and coastal processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to infer and predict patterns from data
Understanding of how changes in one variable might affect another
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to apply oceanographic principles to real-world problems
Understanding of how to structure and formulate scientifically sound projects

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to Matlab programming and to develop skills utilizing this program for data analysis.
Chemical composition of the ocean and the chemical, biological, geological and physical processes controlling it.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of chemical composition of the ocean
Knowledge of biological, geological and physical processes controlling ocean chemistry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of chemical, biological, geological and physical processes
Problem-solving related to oceanic chemical processes

courseDescription: This course examines geochemical processes at and near the Earth’s surface, focusing on the concentration, speciation and reactivity of elements in soils, waters, sediments and the atmosphere.  The course examines both the thermodynamic and kinetic controls on these processes, and the role of biology as a mediator (or facilitator) of these processes.  Anthropogenic impacts on natural geochemical processes are also examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of thermodynamic and kinetic controls
Understanding of the role of biology in geochemical processes
Understanding of anthropogenic impacts on geochemical processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex geochemical processes
Communicating the effects of anthropogenic impacts on natural processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing concentration, speciation and reactivity of elements
Analyzing soils, waters, sediments and the atmosphere

courseDescription: Causes, nature, measurement and analysis of water waves and tides.  Mathematical and graphical application to wave and tide problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Measurement of water waves and tides
Mathematical application to wave and tide problems
Graphical application to wave and tide problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of water waves and tides
Problem-solving in wave and tide issues

courseDescription: The course will consist of brief lectures and hands-on laboratory exercises, in which students will learn to build, use, and debug electronic devices relevant to ocean and earth science applications.  Topics covered will include circuit theory, power supplies and budgets, transducers and amplifiers, computerized data acquisition, instrument control, signal conditioning and resolution.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and resolving issues related to power supplies and budgets

courseDescription: Chemical cycling in lakes and reservoirs, and interactions with biological and physical processes; quantitative modeling of lake geochemistry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biological and physical processes in lakes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing chemical cycling in lakes and reservoirs
Applying quantitative models to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: The course integrates remotely sensed and field techniques for scientific investigation and practical management of coastal environmental systems.  Spatial modeling of coastal processes and management tools using geographic information system (GIS).
Technical and Digital Skills: Practical management of coastal environmental systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting remotely sensed data
Applying spatial models to solve coastal environmental issues

courseDescription: Topics covered will include the occurrence and movement of surface and subsurface water, the nature and distribution of permeable rocks and strata, field techniques used in ground-water studies, and the flow of ground-water to wells.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of surface and subsurface water movement
Knowledge of permeable rocks and strata
Understanding of ground-water flow to wells
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and interpreting complex geological data

courseDescription: This web-based course will provide a practical introduction to oceanography for earth science teachers.  It is particularly aimed at current science teachers attempting to become certified in earth science education.  Topics will include discussions of geological, biological, physical and chemical oceanography.  Not available for credit for OES majors and minors.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying oceanographic concepts in practical scenarios

courseDescription: Introduction to the physics of the earth, including plate tectonics, volcanism, earthquakes and seismology, gravity, the earth's magnetic field, geophysical remote sensing, and mantle convection.
Technical and Digital Skills: Grasp of the earth's magnetic field
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex geophysical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in magnetic field data

courseDescription: A qualitative and quantitative description of physical processes in the Earth and environmental sciences. Topics include stress and strain, plate elasticity and flexure, heat flow, fluid mechanics, material rheology, and groundwater flow. Emphasis will be placed on developing an understanding of Earth dynamics using real-world examples, including numerical exercises.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical processes in Earth and environmental sciences
Knowledge of plate elasticity and flexure
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying understanding of Earth dynamics to real-world problems

courseDescription: Marine organisms and their relationship to physical and chemical processes in the ocean. Laboratory study of local marine organisms, marine ecosystem and sampling techniques.  Includes identification, data analysis and field trips.

courseTitle: Data Collection and Analysis in Oceanography
courseDescription: This course introduces students to the basic oceanographic instruments used to obtain and analyze information by investigating different locations in the Chesapeake Bay. Data obtained with these instruments will be processed and analyzed using the data analysis techniques discussed in class. The data will then be used to answer a particular question related to the temporal and spatial variability in a natural system.

This course will explore the ecology of marine organisms using molecular techniques and data. Molecular ecology covers a wide variety of sub-disciplines, including genetics, physiology, ecology, and evolution. The course will explore basic theory in population genetics, ecology, and evolution and cover nucleic acid techniques and their applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and interpretation of genetic data

courseDescription: Students will be introduced to the science underpinning mitigation of human-induced changes in the Earth system, including but not limited to climate change and sea level rise, and adaptation to the impacts of these changes. The course will cover the environmental hazards and the opportunities and limitations for conservation, mitigation and adaptation. Cross listed with BIOL 566.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of the Earth system and human-induced changes
Understanding of climate change and sea level rise mitigation
Understanding of adaptation strategies to environmental changes
Understanding of conservation, mitigation and adaptation opportunities and limitations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate scientific concepts to diverse stakeholders
Ability to evaluate and communicate environmental risks and opportunities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of mitigation and adaptation strategies
Assessment of conservation, mitigation and adaptation opportunities and limitations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to plan and implement mitigation and adaptation strategies

courseDescription: In this class, students will discover what makes a leader for sustainability. They will consider a range of global and local crises from a leadership point of view in the context of sustainability science, which addresses the development of communities in a rapidly changing social, economic, and environmental system-of-systems environment. The course will be based on taking a problem-motivated and solution-focused approach to the challenges considered. The course includes a service learning project focusing on a leadership experience in solving a real-world environmental problem.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of social, economic, and environmental systems

courseTitle: Proxy Reconstruction of Late Cenozoic Climate: Calibrations and Applications
courseDescription: This course will examine recent developments in paleo-proxy calibration and their application in reconstructing Late Cenozoic climate history. Students will read several papers covering the theoretical basis and empirical evidence supporting some of the most common proxies used in paleoclimatology/paleoceanography each week. Each week will begin with a lecture on the topic, followed by an in-depth discussion.   Students will be required to present two of the weekly topics and lead the class discussion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of recent developments in paleoclimatology/paleoceanography
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical analysis and interpretation of scholarly articles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in climate history reconstruction
Analyzing theoretical basis of paleoclimate proxies

courseDescription: Lectures, field and laboratory studies.  An investigation of a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data collection in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography
Data analysis in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative research in a laboratory setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Investigation of selected problems in oceanography
Critical thinking in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a laboratory setting

courseDescription: Geobiology and the associated field of biosedimentology reflect the interdisciplinary approach to environmental problems, questions related to Earth history, and the exploration of extraterrestrial worlds.  The course elaborates our understanding of geobiology and biosedimentology by conducting a study on benthic cyanobacteria and their influences on sedimentary processes in marine environments.  Study area is Fisherman’s Island, located close to Norfolk, VA.  The course includes aspects of astrobiology (the “sister of geobiology”), and discusses the evolution of life on Earth.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing sedimentary processes in marine environments
Understanding the influence of benthic cyanobacteria

courseDescription: Introduction to descriptive and dynamical physical oceanography.  Properties of sea water; distribution of temperature, salinity and density; water, salt, and heat budgets; techniques for describing the ocean; circulation and water masses of the world's oceans and coastal waters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of properties of sea water
Knowledge of distribution of temperature, salinity and density
Comprehension of water, salt, and heat budgets
Skills in techniques for describing the ocean
Understanding of circulation and water masses of the world's oceans and coastal waters
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to interpret oceanic and coastal water circulation patterns

courseTitle: Introduction to Ocean Modeling and Prediction
courseDescription: Instructor approval required. Introduction to concepts and theories of numerical ocean models and their applications in physical oceanography, computational fluid dynamics, environmental problems and ocean forecast systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of ocean models in physical oceanography
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of environmental problems through ocean models

courseDescription: Provides basic knowledge for conducting field experiments in physical oceanography. Fundamentals of experimental design and sampling theory.  Standard methods of data reduction, analysis, and reporting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Conducting field experiments in physical oceanography

courseTitle: Introduction to Python for Data Analysis
courseDescription: The goal of this class is to introduce students to the Python programming language, and to equip them with basic coding, data management and version control skills that will allow them to get more research done in less time and with less pain (computationally-speaking).

Chemical properties of seawater; chemical composition of the ocean including major and trace elements, dissolved gases, micronutrient elements, and organic compounds; processes controlling this composition.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of chemical properties of seawater
Knowledge of major and trace elements in ocean
Familiarity with dissolved gases in ocean
Insight into micronutrient elements in ocean
Comprehension of organic compounds in ocean
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex chemical phenomena
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of chemical composition of seawater
Interpretation of processes controlling ocean composition

courseDescription: Basic analytical chemistry of seawater; field work in chemical oceanography.
An introduction to the geochemistry of marine sediments, with an emphasis on nutrient (C,N,P,S) and trace element cycling in marine sediments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of nutrient and trace element cycling in marine sediments

courseDescription: Chemical dynamics within water and sediments of estuaries, salt marshes, and the continental shelf; river-sea, air-sea, and sediment-water interactions; modeling techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of chemical dynamics within water and sediments
Knowledge of estuaries, salt marshes, and the continental shelf
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze river-sea, air-sea, and sediment-water interactions
Capability to implement and interpret biogeochemical models

courseDescription: Survey of marine and terrestrial geology and geophysics; plate tectonics and basin formation; marine sediments and sediment dynamics; marine depositional environments and depositional systems; marine stratigraphy dynamics and the formation of marine basins.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of marine depositional environments and systems
Marine stratigraphy dynamics and formation of marine basins
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of geological and geophysical data
Understanding and interpretation of marine stratigraphy dynamics

courseDescription: Techniques used to calculate components of water budgets and groundwater fluxes in coastal systems, including wetlands, tidal rivers, estuaries, and shelf waters. Hydrologic criteria used to delineate wetlands. Many lab exercises will require field work in local wetlands and coastal systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calculating groundwater fluxes in coastal systems
Delineating wetlands based on hydrologic criteria
Performing field work in local wetlands and coastal systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying relevant criteria for wetland delineation

courseDescription: Attributes of marine sediments; main sedimentary facies zones in marine and coastal environments (deep sea, shelf, tidal flats, lagoons, barrier islands); modern depositional systems versus ancient depositional systems; reefs (brachiopoda, corals, sponges, foraminifers, etc); traces and trace fossils.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of modern and ancient depositional systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparison of modern and ancient depositional systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading field studies in marine sedimentology

courseDescription: Dynamics of rotating, stratified fluids, geostrophic adjustment, potential vorticity, Ekman layers, gravity waves, and large scale ocean circulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of rotating, stratified fluids dynamics
Ability to study and interpret gravity waves
Skills in analyzing large scale ocean circulation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and solve problems related to ocean dynamics
Critical evaluation of complex fluid dynamics
Analytical skills in the study of ocean circulation

courseDescription: Marine organisms and their interactions with the physical and chemical environments of the sea;  primary production, population ecology, nutrition, reproduction, and  marine biogeography; related laboratory exercises.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of marine organisms and their environments
Performing laboratory exercises related to marine biology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing interactions between marine organisms and their environments

courseDescription: This course considers the physical oceanography of estuaries.  In particular, it explores how circulation and mixing in estuaries are influenced by atmospheric forcing, tidal forcing, coastal influences and bathymetric variability.  Topics to be treated include classification of estuaries, typical steady dynamical balances, transport of salt and other quantities, mixing, and time-space scales of variability.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of atmospheric and tidal forcing
Understanding of transport of salt and other quantities
Understanding of time-space scales of variability
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex scientific concepts
Collaborative work in a scientific context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving related to estuarine circulation and mixing

courseTitle: Participatory and Agent-Based Modeling, Simulation, and Visualization
courseDescription: Many societal challenges are “wicked problems,” i.e., social or cultural problems that are difficult or impossible to solve. The class will introduce the students to the theory of wicked problems, engage them in transdisciplinary approaches to address such problems using collaborative strategies such as participatory modeling combined with conceptual and agent-based models. Scenario-based simulations and visualizations will be used to explore possible futures and to create foresight related to wicked problems.

Available for pass/fail grading only.  May be repeated for credit.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.

An advanced investigation in a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography under the direction of the faculty of the Department of Ocean, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Investigation of complex problems in oceanography
Analysis and interpretation of oceanographic data

courseDescription: An advanced investigation in a selected problem in physical, geological, chemical, or biological oceanography under the direction of the faculty of the Department of Ocean, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.
Any semester; hours to be arranged; variable credit.  1-9 credits per semester.  M.S.-level research.
Any semester; hours to be arranged; variable credit.  1-9 credits per semester.  M.S.-level work primarily devoted to the writing of the thesis.

This course is designed for incoming graduate students in environmental science disciplines (e.g. oceanography, geography, ecology, geology, biology, etc.) to introduce modern computing software, programming tools and best practices that are broadly applicable to carrying out research in the environmental sciences.   Material covered will include an introduction to Unix, programming using commonly used open-source languages (Python and R), version control and data backup, and data visualization tools for environmental data and making maps. Students will also be introduced to high performance computing and tools for analyzing 'big data' on remote clusters. This course is not discipline specific and is designed to be accessible to any students who want to work with environmental data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing big data on remote clusters
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management with version control tools

courseDescription: A study of the basic techniques used to model and analyze time series of oceanographic data.  These include temporal spatial and frequency/wave number domain techniques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Modeling time series of oceanographic data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing time series of oceanographic data

courseDescription: This is an advanced computational analysis course designed to introduce students to data management and analysis methods commonly used in data science applications. The data analysis portion of the course will be primarily based on machine learning methods. The course will also give an overview of a selection of scientific databases which host freely available oceanographic data and output from numerical model simulations. This course is not discipline specific and will be useful for any students who want to work with data efficiently and gain experience in data management, proper techniques in developing analytical pipelines and applying machine learning to their research.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Efficiently working with oceanographic data and numerical model simulations

courseDescription: Emphasis is on the construction of working ocean models, both vorticity-stream function and primitive equation models analyzed, mostly finite difference techniques, implicit and explicit schemes, staggered grids, discussion of ocean general circulation models.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of vorticity-stream function and primitive equation models
Usage of implicit and explicit schemes
Knowledge of ocean general circulation models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of different simulation techniques for ocean circulation
Problem-solving with implicit and explicit schemes

courseDescription: The regional oceanography of the major ocean basins, marginal seas, and coastal oceans.  Seasonal and interannual variability.  Heat and salt cycles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of heat and salt cycles
Understanding of marginal seas and coastal oceans
Knowledge of seasonal and interannual variability
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to predict seasonal and interannual variability

courseDescription: Dynamics of rotating stratified fluids.  Inertial waves, equatorial dynamics, coastal dynamics, dynamic instability.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret oceanographic data
Problem-solving in the context of ocean dynamics

courseDescription: The course covers the distribution, abundance, and biogeochemical activities of microorganisms in the oceans, with emphasis on prokaryotic microbes and viruses.  Symbioses with higher organisms, and applied aspects of marine microbiology, including biofouling and corrosion, invasive species, and marine biotechnology are also addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification and analysis of prokaryotic microbes and viruses
Understanding of symbioses with higher organisms
Knowledge of biofouling and corrosion processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating in research on marine microorganisms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in microbial biofouling and corrosion
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading studies on marine microbiology applications

courseDescription: This course focuses on the causes (forcings) of climate change; natural response time of the climate system; interactions and feedbacks; and the geologic record in climate change.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding climate system interactions and feedbacks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining natural response time of the climate system

courseDescription: An introduction to the major questions in the management of marine fisheries: abundance, estimation, distribution, recruitment and optimum yield. Topics are presented within the context of fisheries management, marine productivity and population ecology, all of which shape the direction of the primary literature.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of marine productivity and population ecology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to interpret and communicate primary literature
Collaborative problem solving in fisheries management
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of distribution and recruitment in marine fisheries
Critical evaluation of fisheries management strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Direction and synthesis of primary literature

courseDescription: This course is focused on the theory and techniques of mathematical model development for marine ecosystems.  The course is designed to provide an understanding of how to parameterize interaction among components of marine food webs and interaction of food web components with physical environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of mathematical models for marine ecosystems
Parameterization of interactions within marine food webs
Parameterization of interaction between food web components and physical environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and solving of problems within marine food webs
Understanding and predicting changes in physical environments

courseDescription: Sedimentary processes in different coastal zones will be described: carbonate, evaporitic, and clastic depositional systems.  We will conduct a small research project along the coast of Virginia.  Field trip required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of carbonate, evaporitic, and clastic depositional systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of small research project

courseDescription: This class will focus on biologically mediated elemental cycling in aquatic systems.  Assimilatory and dissimilatory biological processes involving auto- and heterotrophic organisms frequently mediate elemental cycling of these elements.  Inorganic compounds and dissolved and particulate organic material will be discussed in terms of their biological reactivity and turnover times in aquatic systems and their contribution to elemental cycling on a variety of temporal and spatial scales.  Also included is the issue of how community structure and function alter biogeochemical cycles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biologically mediated elemental cycling
Knowledge in assimilatory and dissimilatory biological processes
Familiarity with inorganic compounds and dissolved and particulate organic material
Understanding of aquatic systems and their contribution to elemental cycling
Insight into community structure and function in relation to biogeochemical cycles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex biogeochemical concepts
Collaboration with peers in research and data collection
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting data on elemental cycling
Understanding and solving problems related to biological reactivity and turnover times
Analytical skills for studying biogeochemical cycles on various temporal and spatial scales
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Conducting and organizing research in biogeochemistry
Leading discussions on biogeochemical cycle alterations

courseDescription: This course examines the physics, chemistry, biology and ecology of photosynthesis by aquatic organisms.  Topics include light harvesting, energy transfer, carbon metabolism and biosynthesis and their ecological consequences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in biology related to photosynthesis
Skills in carbon metabolism and biosynthesis
Knowledge in light harvesting and energy transfer
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex biological concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in energy transfer and carbon metabolism
Critical thinking in biology, chemistry, and physics contexts

courseDescription: The course covers the physics of light transmission through the aquatic medium as affected by scattering and absorption, the optical properties of seawater, suspended particles of living cells, underwater vision and ocean color.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on optical properties of seawater
Understanding of scattering and absorption in aquatic medium
Knowledge on underwater vision and ocean color
Understanding of suspended particles of living cells
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of light transmission through aquatic medium
Evaluation of optical properties of seawater
Analysis of underwater vision and ocean color

courseDescription: Techniques for presenting scientific data at professional meetings and seminars. Practical experience and feedback from discussions with visiting speakers.

courseDescription: This course emphasizes the ecology of heterotrophic plankton from bacteria to protists, from metazoan invertebrate plankton to fish larvae.  Students will explore the role of plankton groups and species in the context of pelagic ecosystems.  Planktonic processes are not only relevant for the ocean ecosystem but also for fisheries, aquaculture, environmental and human health, and global climate.  The course consists of lectures, discussion groups on selected reading material, and laboratory demonstrations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of plankton groups and species
Understanding of planktonic processes in relation to various industries
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the role of plankton in pelagic ecosystems
Assessment of the significance of planktonic processes for different sectors
